title: Grade 12 - Working With School-Age Children and Adolescents HPD4C (2013)
subject: Social Science and Humanities

document.title: Grade 12 - Working With School-Age Children and Adolescents HPD4C (2013)

86C6CAE7962D47A5AEA8593C413A65D4.description: identify various organizations in the community that provide support to families (e.g., children's aid societies, Dietitians of Canada, police, newcomers' support centres, family counselling agencies, Native friendship centres, breakfast programs)

57C888D4BB8F4C79808595441AB8966B.description: compare various forms of childcare in different cultures (e.g., extended families, kibbutzim)

064B58FDD8144760AFE04B4CE38DE464.description: describe strategies and activities that can be used in formal and informal settings to ensure that environments for children and adolescents are free from bias and respectful of diversity

6E06A21CDE134F0A978B234DEEDBDA38.description: demonstrate an understanding of how expectations related to the behaviour and treatment of children and adolescents vary or have varied in different cultures and historical periods (e.g., up to the industrial period in Western countries, adolescents were viewed as adults)

3DFB1569C1074F8E84B33DD649EA0A15.description: explain how a variety of global challenges (e.g., war, famine, AIDS, use of child labour, natural disasters) affect the lives of children and adolescents

22A7AC79687646F1AC0F24019F67F5FE.description: describe local and global variations in family forms (e.g., extended families, families led by samesex partners, polygamous families)

C1D2C58AEA8E45458AFEAFDD3ECD4CAC.description: Social and Cultural Variations: demonstrate an understanding of how a variety of social and cultural factors affect school-age children and adolescents.

95CB17F0BEFD429896BCFB08B3C080E1.description: describe strategies caregivers can use to anticipate and prevent neglect and physical, sexual, and emotional abuse (e.g., education, communication, policy development, advocacy)

ADACCBFF30AE40AA85FF53000A4A8554.description: demonstrate an understanding that people who work with school-age children and ado - lescents have a duty to report suspected cases of neglect or physical, sexual, or emotional abuse, and describe procedures for doing so

F5D913BE14F94B01898337C482E9D77D.description: identify indicators of neglect and physical, sexual, or emotional abuse in children (e.g., physical signs such as bruising and laceration; emotional signs such as withdrawal or unexplained fears)

4554631A8AAE44088AAAD45C57B00A7C.description: demonstrate an understanding of factors that can lead to patterns of neglect or physical, sexual, or emotional abuse (e.g., a family history of violence, stress, alcoholism)

E07D1C266BA84103AD0ED5BD478E6288.description: Neglect and Abuse: demonstrate an understanding of the responsibilities of people who work with school-age children and adolescents in dealing with issues related to abuse, neglect, and family violence;

49D7296297AF40EAA90446AB5D257211.description: identify specific challenges faced by people who work with school-age children and adolescents, and describe effective strategies for addressing them (e.g., strategies for engaging children with exceptionalities, supporting children living in poverty, responding sensitively and appropriately to diversity)

D2E2726DB102421CA92064ADC0928B72.description: demonstrate an understanding of the positive and negative effects of media on children and adolescents (e.g., positive effects such as enhancing awareness of current events, facilitating social connection through social networking; negative effects such as legitimizing violence, pressuring viewers to purchase fad items, increasing opportunities for cyber-bullying)

1CB4C2878D77408E94F3DF0BCD62561A.description: describe skills caregivers teach (e.g., selfadvocacy skills, stress-management skills, self-defence skills, social skills for making and keeping friends) and strategies they use (e.g., providing appropriate physical/mental-health support) to help children and adolescents address particular issues and challenges

AF34D89620F84E1B910BB6B5138BE91F.description: Issues and Challenges: demonstrate an understanding of a variety of strategies for helping school-age children and adolescents deal with issues and challenges

8891E094F3144BC28A9795E9B44EE2F7.description: evaluate their experiences in working with school-age children and adolescents, and reflect on their potential strengths and areas for improvement

20038DF54CB44E299D6EE2C4F8974637.description: demonstrate the ability to design and implement activities to meet the needs of school-age children and adolescents (e.g., an activity for an after-school program)

27A5BC11CC694C1B9EEC5DC520780A6C.description: identify and use a variety of observation techniques to study children and adolescents in a community setting (e.g., running record, anecdotal record, time sample, video, checklist, event sample)

B07138F5AB154070B1556271309FDC28.description: Refining Skills through Practical Experiences: apply and evaluate their knowledge of child and youth development through practical experiences with school-age children and adolescents.

A801441037244AB9A303E70C636134BE.description: demonstrate the ability to plan nutritious snacks and meals for school-age children and adolescents

4E18DB30B07E46CD8EE1A80D396F08E5.description: identify and plan a variety of activities that promote social, linguistic, emotional, cognitive, and physical development in school-age children and adolescents (e.g., cooperative games, board games)

A97FDBA743EB43A4959EBC694F7645EF.description: Planning Developmentally Appropriate Programming: demonstrate the ability to plan developmentally appropriate programs for school-age children and adolescents;

17C71F70D9B54EA9BFBE331E634996B2.description: explain how experiencing positive relationships with peers and others contributes to healthy social and emotional development in school-age children and adolescents (e.g., by strengthening their sense of belonging, sense of identity, and social skills)

4B1772B16425492EB9C0F4732263D8B0.description: analyse practical experiences with the use of various models for helping children and adolescents make informed decisions (e.g., the five-step model, the decision web, consultation with elders), and evaluate the effectiveness of the different models

89174E43951F4D8B84583BB92574E2FD.description: evaluate the effectiveness of various communication and behaviour-management strat ­ egies in interactions with school-age children and adolescents (e.g., conflict-resolution strategies, win-win problem-solving strategies, “I” messages, paraphrasing, restorative justice, threats)

3A4E35DD04114062B63DAA59BF0FA0E6.description: identify character qualities that can help enable and empower school-age children and adolescents to achieve their goals (e.g., selfcontrol; the ability to set personal limits, anticipate and accept consequences, take responsibility), and describe techniques for promoting the development of these qualities

B1EC0EA7D22E4775AB9D946F93C6D5DA.description: explain various models for effectively guiding child and adolescent behaviour (e.g., the Morrish model, the Faber and Mazlish model)

D108084720EF49C8B75C52DFE4E6CC59.description: Guiding Children�s Behaviour: describe a broad range of practices and techniques adopted by parents, educators, caregivers, and other professionals that shape the behaviour of school-age children and adolescents;

B999D5E5314A407CA0B687626E05B279.description: Interacting with School-Age Children and Adolescents

39422F88A5724E06A5C2176244A89090.description: describe the essential skills and work habits needed for success in working with children and adolescents (e.g., effective interpersonal skills, punctuality, ability to maintain confidentiality, ability to use self-reflection for self-evaluation)

A2F3718FDF0341F6A66B26DBA9A0C8EA.description: identify the personal qualities needed to work with school-age children and adolescents (e.g., compassion, empathy, patience, creativity, flexibility)

59E2C619A50F44B490BB7130B8279CE6.description: explain how their own personal experiences, beliefs, and attitudes have influenced their attitudes and behaviour towards children and adolescents (e.g., experiences, beliefs, and attitudes with respect to family, faith, community, political ideology, socio-economic status)

39AE9CD11EBF4465A5B6F7A1464CCAB8.description: Essential Skills and Personal Qualities: describe the essential skills, personal qualities, and work habits necessary for success in working with school-age children and adolescents.

F20B0EA06FEF48B1B67955986A5816CA.description: explain the code of ethics and standards of practice for people who work with children and adolescents as outlined by recognized professional organizations (e.g., Ontario College of Early Childhood Educators, Canadian Child Care Federation)

A3E75AB843294EB982AD5E7452279D5D.description: identify ways in which people who work with school-age children and adolescents carry out their responsibility to promote children's socialization and healthy development (e.g., teaching life skills; helping youth recognize unhealthy relationships; having open, respectful conversations about sexual development; fostering vigilance about physical safety; fostering environmental awareness; treating all people, including children, equitably regardless of race, sex, ability, or family structure)

35453E0CC32A47B4B134A908DAEF0D53.description: describe the rules and regulations governing schooling that parents and professional caregivers are required to observe (e.g., truancy regulations, provisions of Ontario's Safe Schools Act and Child and Family Services Act, Learning to 18 regulations, requirements for a vulnerable sector criminal check)

89E6B7A313654637BEC18469B5D3A97E.description: describe the legal expectations for ensuring physically safe environments for school-age children and adolescents (e.g., fire-safety regulations, food-safety regulations, WHMIS regulations, the Day Nurseries Act)

BB1963819F1B4E3BAE56B1F5F8ADE9B7.description: demonstrate an understanding of the responsibilities of people who work with school-age children and adolescents as outlined in various local, provincial, federal, and international codes (e.g., school board policies, daycare policies, Ontario's Equity and Inclusive Education Strategy, the Ontario Human Rights Code, the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child)

66E564D478C6442D9606D9E1332B1BF9.description: Workplace Expectations: explain the legal and social workplace expectations related to working with school-age children and adolescents in Ontario;

3902C75AF723403D8708B9C4005B7C41.description: demonstrate an understanding of the importance of professional development for people who work with school-age children and adolescents

54664BCA56EF4A59AC25951863C6DE4D.description: describe and compare a variety of workplace destinations that involve working with school-age children and adolescents (e.g., beforeschool and after-school programs, summer camps, parks and recreation programs, treatment centres)

63F3F44B613A44F6B2188B1BAA144F53.description: identify postsecondary pathways to occupations that involve working with schoolage children and adolescents

AB895007197B4F9E9E4F2A678DA5536C.description: Career Pathways: identify various postsecondary education and/or training opportunities, workplaces, and professional development options related to working with school-age children and adolescents;

28E3E03682D54F129DA0B0B18487E08B.description: explain ways in which the development of school-age children and adolescents is connected to the well-being of their families and the society in which they live (e.g., through access to social supports, access to educational and employment opportunities, access to adequate health care)

4FD6FA8BF58B4DE381720B30C6F2BD9B.description: describe strategies to promote healthy eating among diverse groups of school-age children and adolescents

754F8F1025F4424B9C4DD45BBDD27D81.description: explain how and why physical activity, including physical activity out of doors, promotes the physical and emotional health of school-age children and adolescents (e.g., by providing opportunities for vigorous exercise and connection with the natural environment, by laying the foundation for a healthy lifestyle)

4560084B76984B53BED36AB1800FE605.description: describe strategies for teaching values and building character in school-age children and adolescents (e.g., use of bullying-prevention programs, peer mediation, leadership training courses, cultural literacy programs)

8836815E1E3A4466868146416442A25B.description: describe conditions that promote growth and development in school-age children and adolescents in caregiving contexts (e.g., engaging personal relationships with caring adults, safe spaces)

D5C2460CF8974FC59A75FAB14A96E0E1.description: Positive Environments for Development: demonstrate an understanding of how developmentally appropriate environments and experiences promote healthy development.

FF5E9390EA9F40E4B7848FF542103537.description: demonstrate an understanding of how various theories about child and adolescent development apply to real-life contexts

2F03295BAD314AE1A11F5136ABCC1681.description: outline the theories of recognized experts in the field of child and adolescent development (e.g., theories of Piaget, Erikson, Gilligan, Kohlberg, Gardner)

CB05A076F0C947D28BE80CEE0EE8CC57.description: Theories of Development: demonstrate an understanding of various influential theories about child and adolescent development;

D6FBB3EAA00942BB9F409C9B4CC0AF1F.description: describe the findings of brain research that contribute to our understanding of development in older children and adolescents (e.g., information about blooming and pruning, brain wiring, control centres in the brain for judgement and decision making, development of the frontal lobe in late adolescence)

992638048ED54DACAB7A5174874C091B.description: describe patterns in male and female sexual development and explain how sexual development affects physical, social, and emotional development

04D855495B2F474BA69A9ADB241E8C8D.description: describe indicators of the various types of exceptionalities in school-age children and adolescents (e.g., cognitive, behavioural, physical)

062D465F8DB6435281FB0937FD4FDCC5.description: explain the benefits of healthy eating for the learning, growth, and development of schoolage children and adolescents (e.g., increased ability to concentrate, maintenance of healthy body weight)

AE9DADD675A74B5C9C754C3C58144950.description: identify and compare the nutritional and physical-activity requirements of school-age children and adolescents at different stages, based on current recommendations from Health Canada

1FBEB531C4634C3FA8FD4A860D8056DA.description: explain the interdependence of the social, emotional, cognitive, and physical areas of development (i.e., how development in each of the areas affects development in the others)

73819900B2CF407887474663E5146EC0.description: identify major milestones in the social, emotional, cognitive, and physical development of school-age children and adolescents

D3A08E8C94EC4E909F38659F74C63D02.description: Patterns of Development: demonstrate an understanding of patterns of social, emotional, cognitive, and physical development in school-age children and adolescents;

E8672A222BB14D4D94272CB31EA62327.description: demonstrate an understanding of the general research process by reflecting on and evaluating their own research, inquiry, and communication skills

994858D9086940FCABC4ACCDDD102FF5.description: clearly communicate the results of their inquiries (e.g., write clearly, organize ideas logically, use language conventions properly), and follow APA conventions for acknowledging sources (e.g., generate a reference list in APA style, use in-text author-date citations)

23721A8C2E89452A960BE0D28B3D7E49.description: correctly use terms relating to the study of school-age children and adolescents (e.g., puberty, identity, formal operations, problem-based approach)

E45CD0926E5B40B596AF038735891B3B.description: use an appropriate format (e.g., oral presentation, written research report, poster, multimedia presentation, web page) to communicate the results of their research and inquiry effectively for a specific purpose and audience

3FC1D703915E44CBA1590EBEE484DB6F.description: Communicating and Reflecting: communicate the results of their research and inquiry clearly and effectively, and reflect on and evaluate their research, inquiry, and communication skills.

5BC0F6ACBD9948AEB04888F706B0CE86.description: synthesize findings and formulate conclusions (e.g., determine whether their results support or contradict their hypothesis; weigh and connect information to determine the answer to their research questions)

34626CEDCDC7448EA7BD020D670923F9.description: demonstrate academic honesty by documenting the sources of all information generated through research

3B978CF1550B4331A6202F09C7EC2426.description: analyse and interpret research information (e.g., compare information gathered from surveys and interviews; determine whether similar information is found in different sources)

5415EB6CFD8F41CBA6A0202944F89388.description: record and organize information and key ideas using a variety of formats (e.g., notes, graphic organizers, summaries, audio/digital records)

65737DF9CC984C0496469F60AFA2B254.description: assess various aspects of information gathered from primary and secondary sources (e.g., accuracy, relevance, reliability, inherent values and bias, voice)

469DDC50CE204A2D92FB1742AAABB10A.description: Processing Information: assess, record, analyse, and synthesize information gathered through research and inquiry;

4AE6CABC6D8E4E2F92189C78A0795054.description: based on preliminary research, for each investigation formulate a hypothesis, thesis statement, or research question, and use it to focus their research

910FE7BF6B024410A317202F5B190DCA.description: locate and select information relevant to their investigations from a variety of primary sources (e.g., interviews, observations, surveys, questionnaires, primary research published in peerreviewed journals, data sets from Statistics Canada) and/or secondary sources (e.g., book reviews, government reports, textbooks, websites, brochures, newspaper and magazine articles)

36FEAB2DB48A4B79855AAB469A82539B.description: create appropriate research plans to investigate their selected topics (e.g., outline purpose and method; identify sources of information; develop research tools such as surveys or questionnaires), ensuring that their plans follow guidelines for ethical research

EDC98FA343264E56B5C104C8C736D695.description: Investigating: create research plans, and locate and select information relevant to their chosen topics, using appropriate social science research and inquiry methods;

25C1FD3074CD47689631B34651160B48.description: formulate effective questions to guide their research and inquiry

40065EB8F0AE40A7A445413ACF69BD01.description: identify key concepts (e.g., through discussion, brainstorming, use of visual organizers) related to their selected topics

78996387F7AC4CE7897698921D1D90CE.description: explore a variety of topics related to schoolage children and adolescents (e.g., effects of vigorous physical exercise on school-age children; strategies for developing inclusive and diverse after-school care programs) to identify topics for research and inquiry

A342C6E95E7C4FC4ACB5D9D143C0E3DA.description: Exploring: explore topics related to school-age children and adolescents, and formulate questions to guide their research;
